abstract: Vitality of farming business is spurring lawmakers to call for end to longstanding agricultural subsidy, but some lawmakers and their farm lobby allies are seeking to send that money back to farmers under a new program; lawmakers' reluctance to simply eliminate subsidy without adding another in its place demonstrates how difficult it is for Washington to trim federal largess that flows to any powerful interest group.
snippet: Farming is a very healthy business, spurring calls to end its large government safety net. But some lawmakers want to create a new program instead.
lead_paragraph: Farming is a very healthy business, spurring calls to end its large government safety net. But some lawmakers want to create a new program instead.

headline.main: Farmers Facing Loss of Subsidy May Get New One
headline.print_headline: Farmers Facing Loss of Subsidy May Get New One
headline.seo: When One Farm Subsidy Ends, Another May Rise to Replace It
